title: Kellogg Raises Outlook After Quarterly Sales Rise; Food company says consumer demand held up despite raising its prices
text:
Kellogg's price increases, which led to its products costing nearly 14% more on average, drove the sales growth in the quarter. Consumers pulled back slightly, in part due to its lack of cereal inventory, Kellogg said, and sales volume slipped 1.5%.

"We continue to mitigate the margin pressure created by decades high cost inflation and bottlenecks and shortages evident across the entire economy," said Kellogg Chief Executive Steve Cahillane.

Kellogg, like its peers Coca-Cola Co., Kraft Heinz Co. and Mondelez International Inc., said that after raising its prices, shoppers so far haven't cut back much compared with previous periods of inflation. Several consumer-product and food companies have said they expect people to curb their spending more in the second half of the year.

Kellogg is in the midst of spinning off its North America cereal business and plant-based meat brands, a plan the company announced in June. Kellogg said the separation would help its cereal brands regain their footing on supermarket shelves and fuel faster growth in its stronger snack business.

Shares were about 15% higher this year through Wednesday's close, and rose 2% Thursday.

Kellogg on Thursday said its quarterly sales rose 12% on an organic basis, which strips out impacts from currency, acquisitions and divestitures.

The company raised its outlook for organic sales to grow between 7% and 8% this year, up from its previous view of about 4%. It expects its adjusted operating profit to rise between 4% and 5%, up from its previous projection of between 1% and 2%.

Kellogg said its cereal brands in North America are recovering faster than expected after production was stunted by a plant worker strike and a factory fire last year.

For the period ended July 2, Kellogg reported a decline in profit to $415 million, or 95 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, per-share earnings were $1.18. Revenue rose 9% to $3.86 billion. The results topped analyst expectations of $1.05 per-share earnings on revenue of $3.64 billion, according to FactSet.
